name: Abdominal Muscles
aka: Abdominal Muscle; Muscle, Abdominal; Muscles, Abdominal
description: Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.

name: Abducens Nerve
aka: Nerve, Abducens
description: The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.

name: Acanthocytes
aka: Acanthocyte
description: Erythrocytes with protoplasmic projections giving the cell a thorny appearance.

name: Accessory Nerve
aka: Accessory Nerves; Nerve, Accessory; Nerves, Accessory
description: The 11th cranial nerve which originates from NEURONS in the MEDULLA and in the CERVICAL SPINAL CORD. It has a cranial root, which joins the VAGUS NERVE (10th cranial) and sends motor fibers to the muscles of the LARYNX, and a spinal root, which sends motor fibers to the TRAPEZIUS and the sternocleidomastoid muscles.

name: Acetabulum
aka: Acetabulums
description: The part of the pelvis that comprises the pelvic socket where the head of FEMUR joins to form HIP JOINT (acetabulofemoral joint).

name: Achilles Tendon
aka: Tendon, Achilles
description: Tendon that connects the muscles in the back of the calf to the HEEL BONE.

name: Vestibulocochlear Nerve
aka: Nerve, Vestibulocochlear; Nerves, Vestibulocochlear; Vestibulocochlear Nerves
description: The 8th cranial nerve. The vestibulocochlear nerve has a cochlear part (COCHLEAR NERVE) which is concerned with hearing and a vestibular part (VESTIBULAR NERVE) which mediates the sense of balance and head position. The fibers of the cochlear nerve originate from neurons of the SPIRAL GANGLION and project to the cochlear nuclei (COCHLEAR NUCLEUS). The fibers of the vestibular nerve arise from neurons of Scarpa's ganglion and project to the VESTIBULAR NUCLEI.

name: Acromioclavicular Joint
aka: Acromioclavicular Joints; Joint, Acromioclavicular; Joints, Acromioclavicular
description: The gliding joint formed by the outer extremity of the CLAVICLE and the inner margin of the ACROMION PROCESS of the SCAPULA.

name: Acromion
aka: Acromions
description: The lateral extension of the spine of the SCAPULA and the highest point of the SHOULDER.

name: Acrosome
aka: Acrosomes
description: The cap-like structure covering the anterior portion of SPERM HEAD. Acrosome, derived from LYSOSOMES, is a membrane-bound organelle that contains the required hydrolytic and proteolytic enzymes necessary for sperm penetration of the egg in FERTILIZATION.

name: Adenoids
aka: Adenoid
description: A collection of lymphoid nodules on the posterior wall and roof of the NASOPHARYNX.

name: Adipose Tissue
aka: Tissue, Adipose
description: Specialized connective tissue composed of fat cells (ADIPOCYTES). It is the site of stored FATS, usually in the form of TRIGLYCERIDES. In mammals, there are two types of adipose tissue, the WHITE FAT and the BROWN FAT. Their relative distributions vary in different species with most adipose tissue being white.

name: Adnexa Uteri
description: Appendages of the UTERUS which include the FALLOPIAN TUBES, the OVARY, and the supporting ligaments of the uterus (BROAD LIGAMENT; ROUND LIGAMENT).

name: Adrenal Cortex
aka: Cortex, Adrenal
description: The outer layer of the adrenal gland. It is derived from MESODERM and comprised of three zones (outer ZONA GLOMERULOSA, middle ZONA FASCICULATA, and inner ZONA RETICULARIS) with each producing various steroids preferentially, such as ALDOSTERONE; HYDROCORTISONE; DEHYDROEPIANDROSTERONE; and ANDROSTENEDIONE. Adrenal cortex function is regulated by pituitary ADRENOCORTICOTROPIN.

name: Adrenal Glands
aka: Adrenal Gland; Gland, Adrenal; Glands, Adrenal
description: A pair of glands located at the cranial pole of each of the two KIDNEYS. Each adrenal gland is composed of two distinct endocrine tissues with separate embryonic origins, the ADRENAL CORTEX producing STEROIDS and the ADRENAL MEDULLA producing NEUROTRANSMITTERS.

name: Adrenal Medulla
aka: Adrenal Medullas; Medulla, Adrenal; Medullas, Adrenal
description: The inner portion of the adrenal gland. Derived from ECTODERM, adrenal medulla consists mainly of CHROMAFFIN CELLS that produces and stores a number of NEUROTRANSMITTERS, mainly adrenaline (EPINEPHRINE) and NOREPINEPHRINE. The activity of the adrenal medulla is regulated by the SYMPATHETIC NERVOUS SYSTEM.

name: Adrenergic Fibers
aka: Adrenergic Fiber; Fiber, Adrenergic; Fibers, Adrenergic
description: Nerve fibers liberating catecholamines at a synapse after an impulse.

name: Afferent Pathways
aka: Afferent Pathway; Pathway, Afferent; Pathways, Afferent
description: Nerve structures through which impulses are conducted from a peripheral part toward a nerve center.

name: Alveolar Process
aka: Alveolar Processes; Process, Alveolar; Processes, Alveolar
description: The thickest and spongiest part of the maxilla and mandible hollowed out into deep cavities for the teeth.

name: Amygdala
description: Almond-shaped group of basal nuclei anterior to the INFERIOR HORN OF THE LATERAL VENTRICLE of the TEMPORAL LOBE. The amygdala is part of the limbic system.

name: Ankle Joint
aka: Ankle Joints; Joint, Ankle; Joints, Ankle
description: The joint that is formed by the inferior articular and malleolar articular surfaces of the TIBIA; the malleolar articular surface of the FIBULA; and the medial malleolar, lateral malleolar, and superior surfaces of the TALUS.

name: Anterior Chamber
aka: Anterior Chambers; Chamber, Anterior; Chambers, Anterior
description: The space in the eye, filled with aqueous humor, bounded anteriorly by the cornea and a small portion of the sclera and posteriorly by a small portion of the ciliary body, the iris, and that part of the crystalline lens which presents through the pupil. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed, p109)

name: Anterior Eye Segment
aka: Anterior Eye Segments; Eye Segment, Anterior; Eye Segments, Anterior; Segment, Anterior Eye; Segments, Anterior Eye
description: The front third of the eyeball that includes the structures between the front surface of the cornea and the front of the VITREOUS BODY.

name: Anterior Horn Cells
aka: Anterior Horn Cell; Cell, Anterior Horn; Cells, Anterior Horn
description: MOTOR NEURONS in the anterior (ventral) horn of the SPINAL CORD which project to SKELETAL MUSCLES.

name: Antibody-Producing Cells
aka: Antibody Producing Cells
description: Cells of the lymphoid series that can react with antigen to produce specific cell products called antibodies. Various cell subpopulations, often B-lymphocytes, can be defined, based on the different classes of immunoglobulins that they synthesize.

name: Antigen-Presenting Cells
aka: Antigen Presenting Cells
description: A heterogeneous group of immunocompetent cells that mediate the cellular immune response by processing and presenting antigens to the T-cells. Traditional antigen-presenting cells include MACROPHAGES; DENDRITIC CELLS; LANGERHANS CELLS; and B-LYMPHOCYTES. FOLLICULAR DENDRITIC CELLS are not traditional antigen-presenting cells, but because they hold antigen on their cell surface in the form of IMMUNE COMPLEXES for B-cell recognition they are considered so by some authors.

name: Anal Canal
description: The terminal segment of the LARGE INTESTINE, beginning from the ampulla of the RECTUM and ending at the anus.

name: Aorta
aka: Aortas
description: The main trunk of the systemic arteries.

name: Aorta, Abdominal
aka: Abdominal Aortas; Aortas, Abdominal
description: The aorta from the DIAPHRAGM to the bifurcation into the right and left common iliac arteries.

name: Aorta, Thoracic
description: The portion of the descending aorta proceeding from the arch of the aorta and extending to the DIAPHRAGM, eventually connecting to the ABDOMINAL AORTA.

name: Aortic Bodies
aka: Aortic Body; Bodies, Aortic; Body, Aortic
description: Small clusters of chemoreceptive and supporting cells located near the ARCH OF THE AORTA; the PULMONARY ARTERIES; and the CORONARY ARTERIES. The aortic bodies sense PH; CARBON DIOXIDE; and OXYGEN concentrations in the BLOOD and participate in the control of RESPIRATION. The aortic bodies should not be confused with the PARA-AORTIC BODIES in the abdomen (which are sometimes also called aortic bodies).

name: Aortic Valve
aka: Aortic Valves; Valve, Aortic; Valves, Aortic
description: The valve between the left ventricle and the ascending aorta which prevents backflow into the left ventricle.

name: Apocrine Glands
aka: Apocrine Gland; Gland, Apocrine; Glands, Apocrine
description: Large, branched, specialized sweat glands that empty into the upper portion of a HAIR FOLLICLE instead of directly onto the SKIN.

name: Appendix
description: A worm-like blind tube extension from the CECUM.

name: Aqueous Humor
aka: Aqueous Humors; Humor, Aqueous; Humors, Aqueous
description: The clear, watery fluid which fills the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye. It has a refractive index lower than the crystalline lens, which it surrounds, and is involved in the metabolism of the cornea and the crystalline lens. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed, p319)

name: Arachnoid
aka: Arachnoids
description: A delicate membrane enveloping the brain and spinal cord. It lies between the PIA MATER and the DURA MATER. It is separated from the pia mater by the subarachnoid cavity which is filled with CEREBROSPINAL FLUID.

name: Arcuate Nucleus of Hypothalamus
aka: Hypothalamus Arcuate Nucleus
description: A nucleus located in the middle hypothalamus in the most ventral part of the THIRD VENTRICLE near the entrance of the infundibular recess. Its small cells are in close contact with the EPENDYMA.

name: Bones of Upper Extremity
aka: Upper Extremity Bone; Upper Extremity Bones
description: The bones of the upper and lower ARM. They include the CLAVICLE and SCAPULA.

name: Arm Bones
aka: Arm Bone; Bone, Arm; Bones, Arm
description: The bones of the free part of the upper extremity including the HUMERUS; RADIUS; and ULNA.

name: Arteries
aka: Artery
description: The vessels carrying blood away from the heart.

name: Arterioles
aka: Arteriole
description: The smallest divisions of the arteries located between the muscular arteries and the capillaries.

name: Arteriovenous Anastomosis
aka: Anastomoses, Arteriovenous; Anastomosis, Arteriovenous
description: A vessel that directly interconnects an artery and a vein, and that acts as a shunt to bypass the CAPILLARY BEDS. Not to be confused with SURGICAL ANASTOMOSIS or ARTERIOVENOUS FISTULA.

name: Arytenoid Cartilage
aka: Arytenoid Cartilages; Cartilage, Arytenoid; Cartilages, Arytenoid
description: One of a pair of small pyramidal cartilages that articulate with the lamina of the CRICOID CARTILAGE. The corresponding VOCAL LIGAMENT and several muscles are attached to it.

name: Astrocytes
aka: Astrocyte
description: A class of large neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system - the largest and most numerous neuroglial cells in the brain and spinal cord. Astrocytes (from "star" cells) are irregularly shaped with many long processes, including those with "end feet" which form the glial (limiting) membrane and directly and indirectly contribute to the BLOOD-BRAIN BARRIER. They regulate the extracellular ionic and chemical environment, and "reactive astrocytes" (along with MICROGLIA) respond to injury.

name: Atlanto-Axial Joint
aka: Atlanto-Axial Joints; Joint, Atlanto-Axial; Joints, Atlanto-Axial
description: The joint involving the CERVICAL ATLAS and axis bones.

name: Atlanto-Occipital Joint
aka: Atlanto Occipital Joint; Atlanto-Occipital Joints; Joint, Atlanto-Occipital; Joints, Atlanto-Occipital
description: The point of articulation between the OCCIPITAL BONE and the CERVICAL ATLAS.

name: Cervical Atlas
description: The first cervical vertebra.

name: Atrioventricular Node
aka: Atrioventricular Nodes; Node, Atrioventricular; Nodes, Atrioventricular
description: A small nodular mass of specialized muscle fibers located in the interatrial septum near the opening of the coronary sinus. It gives rise to the atrioventricular bundle of the conduction system of the heart.

name: Auditory Cortex
aka: Cortex, Auditory
description: The region of the cerebral cortex that receives the auditory radiation from the MEDIAL GENICULATE BODY.

name: Auditory Pathways
aka: Auditory Pathway; Pathway, Auditory; Pathways, Auditory
description: NEURAL PATHWAYS and connections within the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM, beginning at the hair cells of the ORGAN OF CORTI, continuing along the eighth cranial nerve, and terminating at the AUDITORY CORTEX.

name: Autonomic Fibers, Postganglionic
aka: Autonomic Fiber, Postganglionic; Fiber, Postganglionic Autonomic; Fibers, Postganglionic Autonomic; Postganglionic Autonomic Fiber; Postganglionic Autonomic Fibers
description: Nerve fibers which project from cell bodies of AUTONOMIC GANGLIA to SYNAPSES on target organs.

name: Autonomic Fibers, Preganglionic
aka: Autonomic Fiber, Preganglionic; Fiber, Preganglionic Autonomic; Fibers, Preganglionic Autonomic; Preganglionic Autonomic Fiber; Preganglionic Autonomic Fibers
description: NERVE FIBERS which project from the central nervous system to AUTONOMIC GANGLIA. In the sympathetic division most preganglionic fibers originate with neurons in the intermediolateral column of the SPINAL CORD, exit via ventral roots from upper thoracic through lower lumbar segments, and project to the paravertebral ganglia; there they either terminate in SYNAPSES or continue through the SPLANCHNIC NERVES to the prevertebral ganglia. In the parasympathetic division the fibers originate in neurons of the BRAIN STEM and sacral spinal cord. In both divisions the principal transmitter is ACETYLCHOLINE but peptide cotransmitters may also be released.

name: Autonomic Nervous System
aka: Autonomic Nervous Systems; Nervous System, Autonomic; Nervous Systems, Autonomic; System, Autonomic Nervous; Systems, Autonomic Nervous
description: The ENTERIC NERVOUS SYSTEM; PARASYMPATHETIC NERVOUS SYSTEM; and SYMPATHETIC NERVOUS SYSTEM taken together. Generally speaking, the autonomic nervous system regulates the internal environment during both peaceful activity and physical or emotional stress. Autonomic activity is controlled and integrated by the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM, especially the HYPOTHALAMUS and the SOLITARY NUCLEUS, which receive information relayed from VISCERAL AFFERENTS.

name: Axillary Artery
aka: Arteries, Axillary; Artery, Axillary; Axillary Arteries
description: The continuation of the subclavian artery; it distributes over the upper limb, axilla, chest and shoulder.

name: Axillary Vein
aka: Axillary Veins; Vein, Axillary; Veins, Axillary
description: The venous trunk of the upper limb; a continuation of the basilar and brachial veins running from the lower border of the teres major muscle to the outer border of the first rib where it becomes the subclavian vein.

name: Axis, Cervical Vertebra
description: The second cervical vertebra.

name: Axons
aka: Axon
description: Nerve fibers that are capable of rapidly conducting impulses away from the neuron cell body.

name: Azygos Vein
aka: Azygos Veins; Vein, Azygos; Veins, Azygos
description: A vein which arises from the right ascending lumbar vein or the vena cava, enters the thorax through the aortic orifice in the diaphragm, and terminates in the superior vena cava.

name: B-Lymphocytes
aka: B Lymphocytes
description: Lymphoid cells concerned with humoral immunity. They are short-lived cells resembling bursa-derived lymphocytes of birds in their production of immunoglobulin upon appropriate stimulation.

name: Bartholin's Glands
aka: Bartholin Glands; Bartholins Glands; Glands, Bartholin's
description: Mucus-secreting glands situated on the posterior and lateral aspect of the vestibule of the vagina.

name: Basal Ganglia
description: Large subcortical nuclear masses derived from the telencephalon and located in the basal regions of the cerebral hemispheres.

name: Claustrum
description: A gray matter lamina located underneath the inner NEOCORTEX lateral to the PUTAMEN and medial to the INSULAR CORTEX. It is considered to be a part of the basal ganglia. Extensive claustral projections exist to most cortices and subcortical structures including the AMYGDALA, the CAUDATE NUCLEUS, the HIPPOCAMPUS and the THALAMUS.

name: Basilar Artery
aka: Arteries, Basilar; Artery, Basilar; Basilar Arteries
description: The artery formed by the union of the right and left vertebral arteries; it runs from the lower to the upper border of the pons, where it bifurcates into the two posterior cerebral arteries.

name: Basophils
aka: Basophil
description: Granular leukocytes characterized by a relatively pale-staining, lobate nucleus and cytoplasm containing coarse dark-staining granules of variable size and stainable by basic dyes.

name: Bile Canaliculi
aka: Bile Canaliculus; Canaliculi, Bile; Canaliculus, Bile
description: Minute intercellular channels that occur between liver cells and carry bile towards interlobar bile ducts. Also called bile capillaries.

name: Bile Ducts
aka: Bile Duct; Duct, Bile; Ducts, Bile
description: The channels that collect and transport the bile secretion from the BILE CANALICULI, the smallest branch of the BILIARY TRACT in the LIVER, through the bile ductules, the bile ducts out the liver, and to the GALLBLADDER for storage.

name: Bile Ducts, Intrahepatic
aka: Bile Duct, Intrahepatic; Duct, Intrahepatic Bile; Ducts, Intrahepatic Bile; Intrahepatic Bile Duct; Intrahepatic Bile Ducts
description: Passages within the liver for the conveyance of bile. Includes right and left hepatic ducts even though these may join outside the liver to form the common hepatic duct.

name: Biliary Tract
aka: Tract, Biliary
description: The BILE DUCTS and the GALLBLADDER.

name: Urinary Bladder
aka: Bladder, Urinary
description: A musculomembranous sac along the URINARY TRACT. URINE flows from the KIDNEYS into the bladder via the ureters (URETER), and is held there until URINATION.

name: Blood
description: The body fluid that circulates in the vascular system (BLOOD VESSELS). Whole blood includes PLASMA and BLOOD CELLS.

name: Blood Cells
aka: Blood Cell; Cell, Blood; Cells, Blood
description: The cells found in the body fluid circulating throughout the CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM.

name: Blood Platelets
aka: Blood Platelet; Platelet, Blood; Platelets, Blood
description: Non-nucleated disk-shaped cells formed in the megakaryocyte and found in the blood of all mammals. They are mainly involved in blood coagulation.

name: Blood Vessels
aka: Blood Vessel; Vessel, Blood; Vessels, Blood
description: Any of the tubular vessels conveying the blood (arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins).

name: Blood-Brain Barrier
aka: Barrier, Blood-Brain; Barriers, Blood-Brain; Blood Brain Barrier; Blood-Brain Barriers
description: Specialized non-fenestrated tightly-joined ENDOTHELIAL CELLS with TIGHT JUNCTIONS that form a transport barrier for certain substances between the cerebral capillaries and the BRAIN tissue.

name: Blood-Retinal Barrier
aka: Barrier, Blood-Retinal; Barriers, Blood-Retinal; Blood Retinal Barrier; Blood-Retinal Barriers
description: A specialized transport barrier, in the EYE, formed by the retinal pigment EPITHELIUM, and the ENDOTHELIUM of the BLOOD VESSELS of the RETINA. TIGHT JUNCTIONS joining adjacent cells keep the barrier between cells continuous.

name: Blood-Testis Barrier
aka: Barrier, Blood-Testis; Barriers, Blood-Testis; Blood Testis Barrier; Blood-Testis Barriers
description: A specialized barrier, in the TESTIS, between the interstitial BLOOD compartment and the adluminal compartment of the SEMINIFEROUS TUBULES. The barrier is formed by layers of cells from the VASCULAR ENDOTHELIUM of the capillary BLOOD VESSELS, to the SEMINIFEROUS EPITHELIUM of the seminiferous tubules. TIGHT JUNCTIONS form between adjacent SERTOLI CELLS, as well as between the ENDOTHELIAL CELLS.

name: Bone and Bones
description: A specialized CONNECTIVE TISSUE that is the main constituent of the SKELETON. The principal cellular component of bone is comprised of OSTEOBLASTS; OSTEOCYTES; and OSTEOCLASTS, while FIBRILLAR COLLAGENS and hydroxyapatite crystals form the BONE MATRIX.

name: Bone Marrow
aka: Marrow, Bone
description: The soft tissue filling the cavities of bones. Bone marrow exists in two types, yellow and red. Yellow marrow is found in the large cavities of large bones and consists mostly of fat cells and a few primitive blood cells. Red marrow is a hematopoietic tissue and is the site of production of erythrocytes and granular leukocytes. Bone marrow is made up of a framework of connective tissue containing branching fibers with the frame being filled with marrow cells.

name: Bone Marrow Cells
aka: Bone Marrow Cell; Cell, Bone Marrow; Cells, Bone Marrow; Marrow Cell, Bone; Marrow Cells, Bone
description: Cells contained in the bone marrow including fat cells (see ADIPOCYTES); STROMAL CELLS; MEGAKARYOCYTES; and the immediate precursors of most blood cells.

name: Brachial Artery
aka: Arteries, Brachial; Artery, Brachial; Brachial Arteries
description: The continuation of the axillary artery; it branches into the radial and ulnar arteries.

name: Brachial Plexus
aka: Plexus, Brachial
description: The large network of nerve fibers which distributes the innervation of the upper extremity. The brachial plexus extends from the neck into the axilla. In humans, the nerves of the plexus usually originate from the lower cervical and the first thoracic spinal cord segments (C5-C8 and T1), but variations are not uncommon.

name: Brain
description: The part of CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that is contained within the skull (CRANIUM). Arising from the NEURAL TUBE, the embryonic brain is comprised of three major parts including PROSENCEPHALON (the forebrain); MESENCEPHALON (the midbrain); and RHOMBENCEPHALON (the hindbrain). The developed brain consists of CEREBRUM; CEREBELLUM; and other structures in the BRAIN STEM.

name: Cerebrum
description: Derived from TELENCEPHALON, cerebrum is composed of a right and a left hemisphere. Each contains an outer cerebral cortex and a subcortical basal ganglia. The cerebrum includes all parts within the skull except the MEDULLA OBLONGATA, the PONS, and the CEREBELLUM. Cerebral functions include sensorimotor, emotional, and intellectual activities.

name: Brain Stem
aka: Brain Stems
description: The part of the brain that connects the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES with the SPINAL CORD. It consists of the MESENCEPHALON; PONS; and MEDULLA OBLONGATA.

name: Breast
aka: Breasts
description: In humans, one of the paired regions in the anterior portion of the THORAX. The breasts consist of the MAMMARY GLANDS, the SKIN, the MUSCLES, the ADIPOSE TISSUE, and the CONNECTIVE TISSUES.

name: Broad Ligament
aka: Broad Ligaments; Ligament, Broad; Ligaments, Broad
description: A broad fold of peritoneum that extends from the side of the uterus to the wall of the pelvis.

name: Bronchi
aka: Bronchus
description: The larger air passages of the lungs arising from the terminal bifurcation of the TRACHEA. They include the largest two primary bronchi which branch out into secondary bronchi, and tertiary bronchi which extend into BRONCHIOLES and PULMONARY ALVEOLI.

name: Bronchioles
description: The small airways branching off the TERTIARY BRONCHI. Terminal bronchioles lead into several orders of respiratory bronchioles which in turn lead into alveolar ducts and then into PULMONARY ALVEOLI.

name: Bronchial Arteries
aka: Arteries, Bronchial; Artery, Bronchial; Bronchial Artery
description: Left bronchial arteries arise from the thoracic aorta, the right from the first aortic intercostal or the upper left bronchial artery; they supply the bronchi and the lower trachea.

name: Adipose Tissue, Brown
aka: Tissue, Brown Adipose
description: A thermogenic form of adipose tissue composed of BROWN ADIPOCYTES. It is found in newborns of many species including humans, and in hibernating mammals. Brown fat is richly vascularized, innervated, and densely packed with MITOCHONDRIA which can generate heat directly from the stored lipids.

name: Brunner Glands
aka: Gland, Brunner; Glands, Brunner
description: The abundant submucosal mucous glands in the DUODENUM. These glands secrete BICARBONATE IONS; GLYCOPROTEINS; and PEPSINOGEN II.

name: Bulbourethral Glands
aka: Bulbourethral Gland; Gland, Bulbourethral; Glands, Bulbourethral
description: Glands situated on each side of the prostate that secrete a fluid component of the seminal fluid into the urethra.

name: Bundle of His
aka: His Bundle
description: Small band of specialized CARDIAC MUSCLE fibers that originates in the ATRIOVENTRICULAR NODE and extends into the membranous part of the interventricular septum. The bundle of His, consisting of the left and the right bundle branches, conducts the electrical impulses to the HEART VENTRICLES in generation of MYOCARDIAL CONTRACTION.

name: Bursa of Fabricius
aka: Fabricius Bursa
description: An epithelial outgrowth of the cloaca in birds similar to the thymus in mammals. It atrophies within 6 months after birth and remains as a fibrous remnant in adult birds. It is composed of lymphoid tissue and prior to involution, is the site of B-lymphocyte maturation.

name: Bursa, Synovial
aka: Bursas, Synovial; Synovial Bursa; Synovial Bursas
description: A fluid-filled sac lined with SYNOVIAL MEMBRANE that provides a cushion between bones, tendons and/or muscles around a joint.

name: Calcaneus
description: The largest of the TARSAL BONES which is situated at the lower and back part of the FOOT, forming the HEEL.

name: Capillaries
aka: Capillary
description: The minute vessels that connect arterioles and venules.

name: Cardia
aka: Cardias
description: That part of the STOMACH close to the opening from ESOPHAGUS into the stomach (cardiac orifice), the ESOPHAGOGASTRIC JUNCTION. The cardia is so named because of its closeness to the HEART. Cardia is characterized by the lack of acid-forming cells (GASTRIC PARIETAL CELLS).

name: Cardiovascular System
aka: Cardiovascular Systems
description: The HEART and the BLOOD VESSELS by which BLOOD is pumped and circulated through the body.

name: Carotid Arteries
aka: Arteries, Carotid; Artery, Carotid; Carotid Artery
description: Either of the two principal arteries on both sides of the neck that supply blood to the head and neck; each divides into two branches, the internal carotid artery and the external carotid artery.

name: Carotid Artery, External
aka: Arteries, External Carotid; Artery, External Carotid; Carotid Arteries, External; External Carotid Arteries; External Carotid Artery
description: Branch of the common carotid artery which supplies the exterior of the head, the face, and the greater part of the neck.

name: Carotid Artery, Internal
aka: Arteries, Internal Carotid; Artery, Internal Carotid; Carotid Arteries, Internal; Internal Carotid Arteries; Internal Carotid Artery
description: Branch of the common carotid artery which supplies the anterior part of the brain, the eye and its appendages, the forehead and nose.

name: Carotid Body
aka: Bodies, Carotid; Body, Carotid; Carotid Bodies
description: A small cluster of chemoreceptive and supporting cells located near the bifurcation of the internal carotid artery. The carotid body, which is richly supplied with fenestrated capillaries, senses the pH, carbon dioxide, and oxygen concentrations in the blood and plays a crucial role in their homeostatic control.

name: Carotid Sinus
aka: Sinus, Carotid
description: The dilated portion of the common carotid artery at its bifurcation into external and internal carotids. It contains baroreceptors which, when stimulated, cause slowing of the heart, vasodilatation, and a fall in blood pressure.

name: Carpal Bones
aka: Bone, Carpal; Bones, Carpal; Carpal Bone
description: The eight bones of the wrist: SCAPHOID BONE; LUNATE BONE; TRIQUETRUM BONE; PISIFORM BONE; TRAPEZIUM BONE; TRAPEZOID BONE; CAPITATE BONE; and HAMATE BONE.

name: Cartilage
aka: Cartilages
description: A non-vascular form of connective tissue composed of CHONDROCYTES embedded in a matrix that includes CHONDROITIN SULFATE and various types of FIBRILLAR COLLAGEN. There are three major types: HYALINE CARTILAGE; FIBROCARTILAGE; and ELASTIC CARTILAGE.

name: Cartilage, Articular
aka: Articular Cartilage; Articular Cartilages; Cartilages, Articular
description: A protective layer of firm, flexible cartilage over the articulating ends of bones. It provides a smooth surface for joint movement, protecting the ends of long bones from wear at points of contact.

name: Cauda Equina
aka: Equina, Cauda
description: The lower part of the SPINAL CORD consisting of the lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal nerve roots.

name: Caudate Nucleus
aka: Nucleus, Caudate
description: Elongated gray mass of the neostriatum located adjacent to the lateral ventricle of the brain.

name: Cavernous Sinus
aka: Sinus, Cavernous
description: An irregularly shaped venous space in the dura mater at either side of the sphenoid bone.

name: Cecum
aka: Cecums
description: The blind sac or outpouching area of the LARGE INTESTINE that is below the entrance of the SMALL INTESTINE. It has a worm-like extension, the vermiform APPENDIX.

name: Celiac Artery
aka: Arteries, Celiac; Artery, Celiac; Celiac Arteries
description: The arterial trunk that arises from the abdominal aorta and after a short course divides into the left gastric, common hepatic and splenic arteries.

name: Celiac Plexus
aka: Plexus, Celiac
description: A complex network of nerve fibers including sympathetic and parasympathetic efferents and visceral afferents. The celiac plexus is the largest of the autonomic plexuses and is located in the abdomen surrounding the celiac and superior mesenteric arteries.

name: Central Nervous System
aka: Central Nervous Systems; Nervous System, Central; Nervous Systems, Central; Systems, Central Nervous
description: The main information-processing organs of the nervous system, consisting of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

name: Cerebellar Cortex
aka: Cortex, Cerebellar
description: The superficial GRAY MATTER of the CEREBELLUM. It consists of two main layers, the stratum moleculare and the stratum granulosum.

name: Cerebellar Nuclei
aka: Cerebellar Nucleus; Nuclei, Cerebellar; Nucleus, Cerebellar
description: Four clusters of neurons located deep within the WHITE MATTER of the CEREBELLUM, which are the nucleus dentatus, nucleus emboliformis, nucleus globosus, and nucleus fastigii.

name: Cerebellopontine Angle
aka: Angle, Cerebellopontine; Angles, Cerebellopontine; Cerebellopontine Angles
description: Junction between the cerebellum and the pons.

name: Cerebellum
aka: Cerebellums
description: The part of brain that lies behind the BRAIN STEM in the posterior base of skull (CRANIAL FOSSA, POSTERIOR). It is also known as the "little brain" with convolutions similar to those of CEREBRAL CORTEX, inner white matter, and deep cerebellar nuclei. Its function is to coordinate voluntary movements, maintain balance, and learn motor skills.

name: Cerebral Aqueduct
aka: Aqueduct, Cerebral; Aqueducts, Cerebral; Cerebral Aqueducts
description: Narrow channel in the MESENCEPHALON that connects the third and fourth CEREBRAL VENTRICLES.

name: Cerebral Arteries
aka: Arteries, Cerebral; Artery, Cerebral; Cerebral Artery
description: The arterial blood vessels supplying the CEREBRUM.

name: Cerebral Cortex
aka: Cerebral Cortices; Cortex, Cerebral
description: The thin layer of GRAY MATTER on the surface of the CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES that develops from the TELENCEPHALON and folds into gyri and sulci. It reaches its highest development in humans and is responsible for intellectual faculties and higher mental functions.

name: Insular Cortex
aka: Cortex, Insular; Insular Cortices
description: A pyramidal shaped region of cerebral cortex located deep below the lateral fissure in PRIMATES. It is surrounded by the SUPERIOR TEMPORAL GYRUS, the rostral PARIETAL LOBE, the INFERIOR FRONTAL GYRUS and the ORBITAL GYRI. It is the primary gustatory cortex and is involved in sensorimotor and somatosensory as well as socioemotional functions.

name: Cerebral Veins
aka: Cerebral Vein; Vein, Cerebral; Veins, Cerebral
description: Veins draining the cerebrum.

name: Cerebral Ventricles
aka: Cerebral Ventricle; Ventricle, Cerebral; Ventricles, Cerebral
description: Four CSF-filled (see CEREBROSPINAL FLUID) cavities within the cerebral hemispheres (LATERAL VENTRICLES), in the midline (THIRD VENTRICLE) and within the PONS and MEDULLA OBLONGATA (FOURTH VENTRICLE).

name: Cervical Plexus
aka: Plexus, Cervical
description: A network of nerve fibers originating in the upper four CERVICAL SPINAL CORD segments. The cervical plexus distributes cutaneous nerves to parts of the neck, shoulders, and back of the head. It also distributes motor fibers to muscles of the cervical SPINAL COLUMN, infrahyoid muscles, and the DIAPHRAGM.

name: Cervical Vertebrae
aka: Vertebrae, Cervical
description: The first seven VERTEBRAE of the SPINAL COLUMN, which correspond to the VERTEBRAE of the NECK.

name: Cervix Uteri
description: The neck portion of the UTERUS between the lower isthmus and the VAGINA forming the cervical canal.

name: Chemoreceptor Cells
aka: Cell, Chemoreceptor; Cells, Chemoreceptor; Chemoreceptor Cell
description: Cells specialized to detect chemical substances and relay that information centrally in the nervous system. Chemoreceptor cells may monitor external stimuli, as in TASTE and OLFACTION, or internal stimuli, such as the concentrations of OXYGEN and CARBON DIOXIDE in the blood.

name: Chin
description: The anatomical frontal portion of the mandible, also known as the mentum, that contains the line of fusion of the two separate halves of the mandible (symphysis menti). This line of fusion divides inferiorly to enclose a triangular area called the mental protuberance. On each side, inferior to the second premolar tooth, is the mental foramen for the passage of blood vessels and a nerve.

name: Cholinergic Fibers
aka: Cholinergic Fiber; Fiber, Cholinergic; Fibers, Cholinergic
description: Nerve fibers liberating acetylcholine at the synapse after an impulse.

name: Chorda Tympani Nerve
aka: Chorda Tympani Nerves; Nerve, Chorda Tympani; Nerves, Chorda Tympani; Tympani Nerve, Chorda; Tympani Nerves, Chorda
description: A branch of the facial (7th cranial) nerve which passes through the middle ear and continues through the petrotympanic fissure. The chorda tympani nerve carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and conveys parasympathetic efferents to the salivary glands.

name: Chordae Tendineae
aka: Tendineae, Chordae
description: The tendinous cords that connect each cusp of the two atrioventricular HEART VALVES to appropriate PAPILLARY MUSCLES in the HEART VENTRICLES, preventing the valves from reversing themselves when the ventricles contract.

name: Chorionic Villi
aka: Chorionic Villus; Villi, Chorionic; Villus, Chorionic
description: Threadlike vascular projections of the chorion. Chorionic villi may be free or embedded within the DECIDUA forming the site for exchange of substances between fetal and maternal blood (PLACENTA).

name: Choroid
aka: Choroids
description: The thin, highly vascular membrane covering most of the posterior of the eye between the RETINA and SCLERA.

name: Choroid Plexus
aka: Plexus, Choroid
description: A villous structure of tangled masses of BLOOD VESSELS contained within the third, lateral, and fourth ventricles of the BRAIN. It regulates part of the production and composition of CEREBROSPINAL FLUID.

name: Chyle
aka: Chyles
description: An opaque, milky-white fluid consisting mainly of emulsified fats that passes through the lacteals of the small intestines into the lymphatic system.

name: Ciliary Body
aka: Bodies, Ciliary; Body, Ciliary; Ciliary Bodies
description: A ring of tissue extending from the scleral spur to the ora serrata of the RETINA. It consists of the uveal portion and the epithelial portion. The ciliary muscle is in the uveal portion and the ciliary processes are in the epithelial portion.

name: Circle of Willis
description: A polygonal anastomosis at the base of the brain formed by the internal carotid (CAROTID ARTERY, INTERNAL), proximal parts of the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries (ANTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY; MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY; POSTERIOR CEREBRAL ARTERY), the anterior communicating artery and the posterior communicating arteries.

name: Cisterna Magna
aka: Magna, Cisterna
description: One of three principal openings in the SUBARACHNOID SPACE. They are also known as cerebellomedullary cistern, and collectively as cisterns.

name: Clavicle
aka: Clavicles
description: A bone on the ventral side of the shoulder girdle, which in humans is commonly called the collar bone.

name: Clitoris
description: An erectile structure homologous with the penis, situated beneath the anterior labial commissure, partially hidden between the anterior ends of the labia minora.

name: Coccyx
description: The last bone in the VERTEBRAL COLUMN in tailless primates considered to be a vestigial tail-bone consisting of three to five fused VERTEBRAE.

name: Cochlear Nerve
aka: Cochlear Nerves; Nerve, Cochlear; Nerves, Cochlear
description: The cochlear part of the 8th cranial nerve (VESTIBULOCOCHLEAR NERVE). The cochlear nerve fibers originate from neurons of the SPIRAL GANGLION and project peripherally to cochlear hair cells and centrally to the cochlear nuclei (COCHLEAR NUCLEUS) of the BRAIN STEM. They mediate the sense of hearing.

name: Colon
description: The segment of LARGE INTESTINE between the CECUM and the RECTUM. It includes the ASCENDING COLON; the TRANSVERSE COLON; the DESCENDING COLON; and the SIGMOID COLON.

name: Common Bile Duct
aka: Bile Duct, Common; Common Bile Ducts; Duct, Common Bile
description: The largest bile duct. It is formed by the junction of the CYSTIC DUCT and the COMMON HEPATIC DUCT.

name: Conjunctiva
aka: Conjunctivas
description: The mucous membrane that covers the posterior surface of the eyelids and the anterior pericorneal surface of the eyeball.

name: Cornea
aka: Corneas
description: The transparent anterior portion of the fibrous coat of the eye consisting of five layers: stratified squamous CORNEAL EPITHELIUM; BOWMAN MEMBRANE; CORNEAL STROMA; DESCEMET MEMBRANE; and mesenchymal CORNEAL ENDOTHELIUM. It serves as the first refracting medium of the eye. It is structurally continuous with the SCLERA, avascular, receiving its nourishment by permeation through spaces between the lamellae, and is innervated by the ophthalmic division of the TRIGEMINAL NERVE via the ciliary nerves and those of the surrounding conjunctiva which together form plexuses. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed)

name: Corneal Stroma
aka: Corneal Stromas; Stroma, Corneal; Stromas, Corneal
description: The lamellated connective tissue constituting the thickest layer of the cornea between the Bowman and Descemet membranes.

name: Coronary Vessels
aka: Coronary Vessel; Vessel, Coronary; Vessels, Coronary
description: The veins and arteries of the HEART.

name: Corpora Allata
aka: Allata, Corpora
description: Paired or fused ganglion-like bodies in the head of insects. The bodies secrete hormones important in the regulation of metamorphosis and the development of some adult tissues.

name: Tectum Mesencephali
aka: Mesencephalus, Tectum; Tectum Mesencephalus
description: The dorsal portion or roof of the midbrain which is composed of two pairs of bumps, the INFERIOR COLLICULI and the SUPERIOR COLLICULI. These four colliculi are also called the quadrigeminal bodies (TECTUM MESENCEPHALI). They are centers for sensorimotor integration.

name: Corpus Callosum
aka: Callosum, Corpus; Callosums, Corpus; Corpus Callosums
description: Broad plate of dense myelinated fibers that reciprocally interconnect regions of the cortex in all lobes with corresponding regions of the opposite hemisphere. The corpus callosum is located deep in the longitudinal fissure.

name: Corpus Luteum
description: The yellow body derived from the ruptured OVARIAN FOLLICLE after OVULATION. The process of corpus luteum formation, LUTEINIZATION, is regulated by LUTEINIZING HORMONE.

name: Corpus Striatum
aka: Striatum, Corpus
description: Striped GRAY MATTER and WHITE MATTER consisting of the NEOSTRIATUM and paleostriatum (GLOBUS PALLIDUS). It is located in front of and lateral to the THALAMUS in each cerebral hemisphere. The gray substance is made up of the CAUDATE NUCLEUS and the lentiform nucleus (the latter consisting of the GLOBUS PALLIDUS and PUTAMEN). The WHITE MATTER is the INTERNAL CAPSULE.

name: Cranial Fossa, Posterior
aka: Cranial Fossas, Posterior; Fossa, Posterior Cranial; Fossas, Posterior Cranial; Posterior Cranial Fossa; Posterior Cranial Fossas
description: The infratentorial compartment that contains the CEREBELLUM and BRAIN STEM. It is formed by the posterior third of the superior surface of the body of the sphenoid (SPHENOID BONE), by the occipital, the petrous, and mastoid portions of the TEMPORAL BONE, and the posterior inferior angle of the PARIETAL BONE.

name: Cranial Nerves
aka: Cranial Nerve; Nerve, Cranial; Nerves, Cranial
description: Twelve pairs of nerves that carry general afferent, visceral afferent, special afferent, somatic efferent, and autonomic efferent fibers.

name: Cranial Sinuses
aka: Sinuses, Cranial
description: Large endothelium-lined venous channels situated between the two layers of DURA MATER, the endosteal and the meningeal layers. They are devoid of valves and are parts of the venous system of dura mater. Major cranial sinuses include a postero-superior group (such as superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, straight, transverse, and occipital) and an antero-inferior group (such as cavernous, petrosal, and basilar plexus).

name: Cranial Sutures
aka: Cranial Suture; Suture, Cranial; Sutures, Cranial
description: A type of fibrous joint between bones of the head.

name: Cricoid Cartilage
aka: Cartilage, Cricoid; Cartilages, Cricoid; Cricoid Cartilages
description: The small thick cartilage that forms the lower and posterior parts of the laryngeal wall.

name: Cystic Duct
aka: Cystic Ducts; Duct, Cystic; Ducts, Cystic
description: The duct that is connected to the GALLBLADDER and allows the emptying of bile into the COMMON BILE DUCT.

name: Decidua
aka: Deciduas
description: The hormone-responsive glandular layer of ENDOMETRIUM that sloughs off at each menstrual flow (decidua menstrualis) or at the termination of pregnancy. During pregnancy, the thickest part of the decidua forms the maternal portion of the PLACENTA, thus named decidua placentalis. The thin portion of the decidua covering the rest of the embryo is the decidua capsularis.

name: Deciduoma
aka: Deciduomas
description: An intrauterine mass containing decidual cells (DECIDUA) or with structures resembling the PLACENTA. Deciduomas usually are induced experimentally.

name: Vestibular Nucleus, Lateral
aka: Nucleus, Lateral Vestibular
description: Vestibular nucleus lying immediately superior to the inferior vestibular nucleus and composed of large multipolar nerve cells. Its upper end becomes continuous with the superior vestibular nucleus.

name: Dendrites
aka: Dendrite
description: Extensions of the nerve cell body. They are short and branched and receive stimuli from other NEURONS.

name: Dendritic Cells
aka: Cell, Dendritic; Cells, Dendritic; Dendritic Cell
description: Specialized cells of the hematopoietic system that have branch-like extensions. They are found throughout the lymphatic system, and in non-lymphoid tissues such as SKIN and the epithelia of the intestinal, respiratory, and reproductive tracts. They trap and process ANTIGENS, and present them to T-CELLS, thereby stimulating CELL-MEDIATED IMMUNITY. They are different from the non-hematopoietic FOLLICULAR DENDRITIC CELLS, which have a similar morphology and immune system function, but with respect to humoral immunity (ANTIBODY PRODUCTION).

name: Dental Arch
description: The curve formed by the row of TEETH in their normal position in the JAW. The inferior dental arch is formed by the mandibular teeth, and the superior dental arch by the maxillary teeth.

name: Dentition
aka: Dentitions
description: The teeth collectively in the dental arch. Dentition ordinarily refers to the natural teeth in position in their alveoli. Dentition referring to the deciduous teeth is DENTITION, PRIMARY; to the permanent teeth, DENTITION, PERMANENT. (From Jablonski, Dictionary of Dentistry, 1992)

name: Pericardial Fluid
aka: Fluid, Pericardial; Fluids, Pericardial; Pericardial Fluids
description: Watery fluid produced in the serous and visceral pericardium surrounding the surface of the HEART.

name: Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex
aka: Cortex, Dorsolateral Prefrontal; Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortices
description: The upper surfaces of the prefrontal cortex comprising the rostral parts of the superior frontal gyrus and the middle frontal gyrus. It is involved in EXECUTIVE FUNCTION.

name: Plantar Plate
aka: Plantar Plates; Plate, Plantar; Plates, Plantar
description: Fibrocartilaginous ligament at the metatarsophalangeal and the interphalangeal joint of the toe.

name: Bone-Implant Interface
aka: Bone Implant Interface; Bone-Implant Interfaces; Interface, Bone-Implant; Interfaces, Bone-Implant
description: Region of interaction between the bone and PROSTHESES AND IMPLANTS which becomes bonded through cellular and extracellular interactions similar to OSSEOINTEGRATION.

name: Round Ligament of Uterus
aka: Uterus Round Ligament; Uterus Round Ligaments
description: A fibromuscular band that attaches to the UTERUS and then passes along the BROAD LIGAMENT, out through the INGUINAL RING, and into the labium majus.

name: Round Ligament of Liver
aka: Liver Round Ligament; Liver Round Ligaments
description: A cord-like remnant structure formed from the closed left fetal UMBILICAL VEIN. It is located along the lower edge of the falciform ligament.

name: Round Ligament of Femur
aka: Femur Round Ligament; Femur Round Ligaments
description: Ligament that connects the fovea of the FEMUR HEAD and the ACETABULUM notch in the HIP JOINT.

name: Descemet Membrane
aka: Descemet Membranes; Membrane, Descemet; Membranes, Descemet
description: A layer of the cornea. It is the basal lamina of the CORNEAL ENDOTHELIUM (from which it is secreted) separating it from the CORNEAL STROMA. It is a homogeneous structure composed of fine collagenous filaments, and slowly increases in thickness with age.

name: Adipose Tissue, Beige
aka: Adipose Tissues, Beige; Beige Adipose Tissues; Tissue, Beige Adipose; Tissues, Beige Adipose
description: Brown fat-like adipose tissue that develops in WHITE ADIPOSE TISSUE from non-MYOGENIC REGULATORY FACTOR 5 expressing cell lineage.

name: Coracoid Process
aka: Coracoid Processes
description: A beak-like bone projection located at the lateral end of the superior anterior border of the SCAPULA.

name: Aponeurosis
description: The flattened and/or expanded “tendon-like” dense fibrous connective tissue that connects skeletal muscles to each other or to bone.

name: Rib Cage
aka: Rib Cages
description: The bony thoracic enclosure consisting of the vertebral column; the RIBS; the STERNUM; and the COSTAL CARTILAGE.

name: Nucleus Pulposus
description: Fibrocartilage inner core of the intervertebral disc. Prolapsed or bulged nucleus pulposus leads to INTERVERTEBRAL DISC DISPLACEMENT while proliferation of cells in the nucleus pulposus is associated with INTERVERTEBRAL DISC DEGENERATION.

name: Annulus Fibrosus
description: Outer portion of the intervertebral disc that surrounds the NUCLEUS PULPOSUS.

name: Hamstring Tendons
aka: Hamstring Tendon; Tendon, Hamstring; Tendons, Hamstring
description: A group of tendons that attach the HAMSTRING MUSCLES proximally to the PELVIS and to the TIBIA and FIBULA at the KNEE JOINT.

name: Hamstring Muscles
aka: Hamstring Muscle; Muscle, Hamstring; Muscles, Hamstring
description: A group of muscles in the posterior THIGH area that are involved in connecting the KNEE JOINT and the PELVIS.

name: Collateral Ligament, Ulnar
aka: Collateral Ligaments, Ulnar; Ligament, Ulnar Collateral; Ligaments, Ulnar Collateral
description: The internal lateral ligament that travels from the medial aspect of the ELBOW uniting the distal aspect of the HUMERUS to the proximal aspect of the ULNA.

name: Sentinel Lymph Node
aka: Lymph Node, Sentinel; Lymph Nodes, Sentinel; Sentinel Lymph Nodes
description: First lymph node to receive drainage from the primary tumor. SENTINEL LYMPH NODE BIOPSY is performed to determine early METASTASIS status because cancer cells may appear first in the sentinel node.

name: Place Cells
aka: Cell, Place; Cells, Place; Place Cell
description: Pyramidal neurons in the HIPPOCAMPUS that play a role in cognitive representation of a specific location within a space.

name: Grid Cells
aka: Cell, Grid; Cells, Grid; Grid Cell
description: Neurons in the ENTORHINAL CORTEX that project to the HIPPOCAMPUS. Grid cells and PLACE CELLS play a role in cognitive representation of spatial memory and navigation.

name: Perirhinal Cortex
aka: Cortex, Perirhinal; Perirhinal Cortices
description: An area in the temporal lobe that is important for memory encoding and retrieval. It is bordered caudally by the parahippocampal cortex (see HIPPOCAMPUS) and ventrally and medially by the ENTORHINAL CORTEX.

name: Axon Initial Segment
description: First segment of axon that connects distal axon segments to the neuronal CELL BODY at the axon hillock region. The axon initial segment is not protected by the MYELIN SHEATH and has properties critical for axonal growth. The axon initial segment and the axon hillock form an axonal trigger zone.

name: Esophageal Mucosa
aka: Mucosa, Esophageal
description: Circular innermost layer of the ESOPHAGUS wall that mediates esophageal PERISTALSIS which pushes ingested food bolus toward the stomach.

name: Abdominal Oblique Muscles
aka: Abdominal Oblique Muscle; Muscle, Abdominal Oblique; Muscles, Abdominal Oblique
description: Muscles of the anterolateral abdominal wall consisting of the external oblique and the internal oblique muscles. The external abdominal oblique muscle fibers extend from lower thoracic ribs to the linea alba and the iliac crest. The internal abdominal oblique extend superomedially beneath the external oblique muscles.

name: Gracilis Muscle
aka: Gracilis Muscles; Muscle, Gracilis; Muscles, Gracilis
description: A slender and most superficial muscle in the inner THIGH which originates at the ramus of the PUBIC BONE near the PUBIC SYMPHYSIS and inserts at the proximal medial TIBIA. Its function is to abduct thigh, flex knee, and rotate leg medially. It is a common  source of a MYOCUTANEOUS FLAP.

name: Meniscus
description: Crescent-shaped cartilaginous tissue interposed between two articulating bones.

name: Mucosal-Associated Invariant T Cells
aka: Mucosal Associated Invariant T Cells
description: A subset of T-lymphocytes that are present in large numbers at MUCOUS MEMBRANES and respond to INFECTIONS. They express a conserved invariant T-CELL RECEPTOR ALPHA-CHAIN that enables them to respond to infections by sensing RIBOFLAVIN metabolites of pathogens.

name: Tertiary Lymphoid Structures
aka: Lymphoid Structure, Tertiary; Lymphoid Structures, Tertiary; Tertiary Lymphoid Structure
description: Aggregates of immune cells formed near the sites of chronically inflamed, infected, or tumorous tissues.

name: Platelet-Rich Fibrin
aka: Fibrin, Platelet-Rich; Platelet Rich Fibrin
description: A fibrin matrix derived from platelet-rich plasma that contains high concentration of BLOOD PLATELETS; LEUKOCYTES; CYTOKINES; and GROWTH FACTORS. It is used in a variety of clinical and TISSUE ENGINEERING applications.

name: Diaphragm
aka: Diaphragms
description: The musculofibrous partition that separates the THORACIC CAVITY from the ABDOMINAL CAVITY. Contraction of the diaphragm increases the volume of the thoracic cavity aiding INHALATION.

name: Oligodendrocyte Precursor Cells
aka: Cell, Oligodendrocyte Precursor; Cells, Oligodendrocyte Precursor; Oligodendrocyte Precursor Cell; Precursor Cell, Oligodendrocyte; Precursor Cells, Oligodendrocyte
description: Neuroglial cells that first appear during mid-embryogenesis in the central nervous system of mammals and give rise to OLIGODENDROCYTES. Mitotically-active populations remain through late adulthood and are capable of regenerating MYELIN lost to disease or injury.

name: Suprachiasmatic Nucleus Neurons
aka: Suprachiasmatic Nucleus Neuron
description: Neurons of the SUPRACHIASMATIC NUCLEUS.

name: Intraepithelial Lymphocytes
description: T Lymphocytes with limited diversity of receptors (e.g., ALPHA E INTEGRINS) in the epidermis of the skin and the mucosal linings. They recognize common microbes via T-CELL RECEPTORS and PATHOGEN-ASSOCIATED MOLECULAR PATTERN MOLECULES and function as effector cells for INNATE IMMUNITY. Activation of intraepithelial lymphocytes is a marker for various gastrointestinal diseases (e.g., CELIAC DISEASE; HAIRY CELL LEUKEMIA; and ENTEROPATHY-ASSOCIATED T-CELL LYMPHOMA).

name: Diencephalon
description: The paired caudal parts of the PROSENCEPHALON from which the THALAMUS; HYPOTHALAMUS; EPITHALAMUS; and SUBTHALAMUS are derived.

name: Digestive System
description: A group of organs stretching from the MOUTH to the ANUS, serving to breakdown foods, assimilate nutrients, and eliminate waste. In humans, the digestive system includes the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT and the accessory glands (LIVER; BILIARY TRACT; PANCREAS).

name: Gastric Artery
aka: Arteries, Gastric; Artery, Gastric; Gastric Arteries
description: Any of several branches of the SPLENIC ARTERY distributed to the greater curvature of the stomach.

name: Glymphatic System
description: A vascular waste clearance system in the brain analogous to the lymphatic system that facilitates transporting of solutes and waste products from CEREBROSPINAL FLUID (CSF) and brain INTERSTITIAL FLUID (ISF). CSF from the SUBARACHNOID SPACE enters the brain periarterial spaces, into the interstitium via channels (e.g., AQUAPORIN 4 PROTEIN) on astrocytic endfeet and exchanges with brain ISF before perivenous drainage of solutes and waste.

name: Mental Foramen
description: An opening on the anterolateral aspect of the MANDIBLE through which the mental nerve bundle and vessels exit.

name: Jugular Foramina
aka: Foramina, Jugular
description: A pair of openings from the posterior cranial fossa through which the GLOSSOPHARYNGEAL NERVE; VAGUS NERVE; ACCESSORY NERVE and the internal JUGULAR VEINS pass.

name: Infratemporal Fossa
aka: Fossa, Infratemporal
description: The compartment that lies posterior to the MAXILLA and inferior to the side wall of the SKULL deep to the ramus of the MANDIBLE. It contains several FACIAL NERVES and the CAROTID ARTERIES and the JUGULAR VEINS.

name: Parapharyngeal Space
description: The deep neck space near the PHARYNX located anterior to the ptyergomandibular raphe,  posterior to the prevertebral fascia, inferior to the SKULL BASE, and superior to the HYOID BONE. Prestyloid parapharyngeal space contains cranial nerves IX, X, XI, XII and internal JUGULAR VEIN and internal CAROTID ARTERY.  Poststyloid parapharyngeal space contains AURICULARTEMPORAL NERVE and MAXILLARY ARTERY and ascending pharyngeal artery.

name: Cerebellar Golgi Cells
aka: Cerebellar Golgi Cell; Golgi Cell, Cerebellar; Golgi Cells, Cerebellar
description: Inhibitory interneurons embedded in the granular layer of the CEREBELLAR CORTEX.

name: Dorsomedial Hypothalamic Nucleus
aka: Nucleus, Dorsomedial Hypothalamic
description: An aggregation of cells in the middle hypothalamus dorsal to the ventromedial nucleus and bordering the THIRD VENTRICLE.

name: Default Mode Network
aka: Network, Default Mode
description: Brain regions which are functionally-connected that are active during resting state and deactivated when engaged in task- or attention-oriented behavioral activities as seen in cognitive imaging studies often with fMRI.

name: Uncinate Fasciculus
aka: Fasciculus, Uncinate
description: A hook-shaped WHITE MATTER axon tract that connects the uncus and pole of the TEMPORAL LOBE, the LIMBIC SYSTEM and the FRONTAL LOBE. It innervates AMYGDALA proper.

name: Vertebral Body
aka: Body, Vertebral; Vertebral Bodies
description: Main portion of the vertebra which bears majority of the weight.

name: T Follicular Helper Cells
description: A specialized subpopulation of CD4+ T cells involved in formation of GERMINAL CENTER. Tfh cells are mostly located in secondary lymphoid organs, e.g., TONSIL; SPLEEN and LYMPH NODES. They are CD4 ANTIGEN; CD45 ANTIGEN; B-CELL LYMPHOMA 6 PROTEIN; CXCR5 RECEPTORS; ICOS INDUCIBLE T-CELL CO-STIMULATOR; and PD1 RECEPTOR positive.

name: Tumor-Associated Macrophages
aka: Macrophage, Tumor-Associated; Tumor Associated Macrophages
description: Various macrophages found in TUMOR MICROENVIRONMENT. They may interact with tumor cells to influence growth and NEOPLASTIC PROCESSES.

name: Sympathoadrenal System
description: A connection of the SYMPATHETIC NERVOUS SYSTEM and the ADRENAL MEDULLA of the ADRENAL GLANDS. Intra-adrenal connection from the medulla to the cortex connects the system to other neuroendocrine systems, which in concert participate in FLIGHT REACTION in stress situations. CATECHOLAMINES are the principle hormone in the system.

name: Ductus Arteriosus
aka: Arteriosus, Ductus
description: A fetal blood vessel connecting the pulmonary artery with the descending aorta.

name: Duodenum
aka: Duodenums
description: The shortest and widest portion of the SMALL INTESTINE adjacent to the PYLORUS of the STOMACH. It is named for having the length equal to about the width of 12 fingers.

name: Dura Mater
description: The outermost of the three MENINGES, a fibrous membrane of connective tissue that covers the brain and the spinal cord.

name: Ear Cartilage
aka: Cartilage, Ear; Cartilages, Ear
description: Cartilage of the EAR AURICLE and the EXTERNAL EAR CANAL.

name: Eccrine Glands
aka: Eccrine Gland; Gland, Eccrine; Glands, Eccrine
description: Simple sweat glands that secrete sweat directly onto the SKIN.

name: Efferent Pathways
aka: Efferent Pathway; Pathway, Efferent; Pathways, Efferent
description: Nerve structures through which impulses are conducted from a nerve center toward a peripheral site. Such impulses are conducted via efferent neurons (NEURONS, EFFERENT), such as MOTOR NEURONS, autonomic neurons, and hypophyseal neurons.

name: Ejaculatory Ducts
aka: Duct, Ejaculatory; Ducts, Ejaculatory; Ejaculatory Duct
description: Paired ducts in the human male through which semen is ejaculated into the urethra.

name: Elbow Joint
aka: Elbow Joints; Joint, Elbow; Joints, Elbow
description: A hinge joint connecting the FOREARM to the ARM.

name: Endocardium
aka: Endocardiums
description: The innermost layer of the heart, comprised of endothelial cells.

name: Mandibular Canal
aka: Canal, Mandibular; Mandibular Canals
description: Internal aspect of the mandible from the MENTAL FORAMEN to the mandibular foramen which serves as the conduit for the INFERIOR ALVEOLAR NERVE and the inferior alveolar artery and vein. Bifid and trifid mandibular canals are normal anatomical variants.

name: Endometrium
description: The mucous membrane lining of the uterine cavity that is hormonally responsive during the MENSTRUAL CYCLE and PREGNANCY. The endometrium undergoes cyclic changes that characterize MENSTRUATION. After successful FERTILIZATION, it serves to sustain the developing embryo.

name: Endothelium, Corneal
description: Single layer of large flattened cells covering the surface of the cornea.

name: Endothelium, Lymphatic
description: Unbroken cellular lining (intima) of the lymph vessels (e.g., the high endothelial lymphatic venules). It is more permeable than vascular endothelium, lacking selective absorption and functioning mainly to remove plasma proteins that have filtered through the capillaries into the tissue spaces.

name: Endothelium, Vascular
description: Single pavement layer of cells which line the luminal surface of the entire vascular system and regulate the transport of macromolecules and blood components.

name: Enterochromaffin Cells
aka: Cell, Enterochromaffin; Cells, Enterochromaffin; Enterochromaffin Cell
description: A subtype of enteroendocrine cells found in the gastrointestinal MUCOSA, particularly in the glands of PYLORIC ANTRUM; DUODENUM; and ILEUM. These cells secrete mainly SEROTONIN and some neuropeptides. Their secretory granules stain readily with silver (argentaffin stain).

name: Memory B Cells
aka: B Cell, Memory; Memory B Cell
description: A subset of activated B cells generated in response to primary immune challenge or immunization which are capable of giving rise to antibody-secreting cells upon re-challenge (see IMMUNOLOGIC MEMORY). Memory B cells feature many discrete properties indicative of differentiation through ISOTYPE SWITCHING and/or IMMUNOGLOBULIN SOMATIC HYPERMUTATION for rapid and robust recall of specific antibody responses.

name: Memory T Cells
aka: Memory T Cell; T Cell, Memory
description: A subset of activated T cells generated in response to primary immune challenge or immunization upon re-challenge (see IMMUNOLOGIC MEMORY). Memory T cells feature many discrete properties indicative of various differentiation such as expression pattern of CCR7 RECEPTORS and can be divided into central memory and effector memory T cells.

name: Schlemm's Canal
aka: Canal, Schlemm's; Schlemm's Canals; Schlemms Canal
description: A circular vascular-like structure in the anterior chamber of the eye bounded anterolaterally by the internal scleral sulcus and posteriorly by the trabecular meshwork. It is a part of a pathway where the AQUEOUS HUMOR from the ANTERIOR CHAMBER of the eye passes through the TRABECULAR MESHWORK, drains into the lumen of Schlemm’s canal, and subsequently returns to blood circulation into the veins of the SCLERA.

name: Eosinophils
aka: Eosinophil
description: Granular leukocytes with a nucleus that usually has two lobes connected by a slender thread of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing coarse, round granules that are uniform in size and stainable by eosin.

name: Ependyma
aka: Ependymas
description: A thin membrane that lines the CEREBRAL VENTRICLES and the central canal of the SPINAL CORD.

name: Epidermis
description: The external, nonvascular layer of the skin. It is made up, from within outward, of five layers of EPITHELIUM: (1) basal layer (stratum basale epidermidis); (2) spinous layer (stratum spinosum epidermidis); (3) granular layer (stratum granulosum epidermidis); (4) clear layer (stratum lucidum epidermidis); and (5) horny layer (stratum corneum epidermidis).

name: Medium Spiny Neurons
aka: Medium Spiny Neuron; Neuron, Medium Spiny
description: Medium sized, inhibitory GABAergic neurons in the CORPUS STRIATUM with highly developed dendritic trees. They are divided into neurons expressing DOPAMINE D1 RECEPTORS which project preferentially to the SUBSTANTIA NIGRA PARS RETICULATA and neurons expressing DOPAMINE D2 RECEPTORS which project preferentially to the lateral part of the GLOBUS PALLIDUS. Medium spiny neurons are preferentially lost in HUNTINGTON DISEASE.

name: Myotendinous Junction
aka: Junction, Myotendinous; Myotendinous Junctions
description: A specialized interface between muscle and tendon through which most contractile force is transmitted. It consists of elaborate surface folding called interdigitations involving EXTRACELLULAR MATRIX and terminal SARCOMERES.

name: Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Gonadal Axis
aka: Axis, Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Gonadal; Hypothalamic Pituitary Gonadal Axis
description: A collection of NEURONS, tracts of NERVE FIBERS, endocrine tissue, and blood vessels in the HYPOTHALAMUS, the PITUITARY GLAND and the GONADS. It plays a central role in endocrine regulation of gonadal function including release of hormones: GNRH; LUTEINIZING HORMONE; FOLLICLE-STIMULATING HORMONE and TESTOSTERONE.

name: Epididymis
description: The convoluted cordlike structure attached to the posterior of the TESTIS. Epididymis consists of the head (caput), the body (corpus), and the tail (cauda). A network of ducts leaving the testis joins into a common epididymal tubule proper which provides the transport, storage, and maturation of SPERMATOZOA.

name: Epidural Space
aka: Epidural Spaces; Space, Epidural; Spaces, Epidural
description: Space between the dura mater and the walls of the vertebral canal.

name: Epiglottis
description: A thin leaf-shaped cartilage that is covered with LARYNGEAL MUCOSA and situated posterior to the root of the tongue and HYOID BONE. During swallowing, the epiglottis folds back over the larynx inlet thus prevents foods from entering the airway.

name: Tuft Cells
aka: Cell, Tuft; Tuft Cell
description: Epithelial chemosensory cells with apical microvilli. They are found in many different organs and they share characteristics with the chemosensory cells in taste buds. These cells can be activated by infections in the gastrointestinal tract.

name: Epicardial Adipose Tissue
aka: Adipose Tissue, Epicardial; Epicardial Adipose Tissues; Tissue, Epicardial Adipose
description: A fat deposit localized between the MYOCARDIUM and the visceral layer of the serous PERICARDIUM. Epicardial adipose tissue is a risk factor for various CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES.

name: Inferior Olivary Complex
aka: Olivary Complex, Inferior
description: A brainstem nucleus in the superior medulla and a part of the OLIVARY NUCLEUS complex. Inferior olivary complex integrates motor and proprioceptive inputs and provides feedback to cerebellar neurons.

name: Epiphyses
description: The head of a long bone that is separated from the shaft by the epiphyseal plate until bone growth stops. At that time, the plate disappears and the head and shaft are united.

name: Tibiofemoral Joint
aka: Joint, Tibiofemoral; Tibiofemoral Joints
description: The articulation between the articular surfaces of the TIBIA and the FEMUR.

name: Ganglionic Eminence
aka: Eminence, Ganglionic
description: A transitory embryonic structure that appears during the 5th week post-fertilization. The ganglionic eminence plays an important in the development of the nervous system by guiding tangential cell and axon migration during embryonic development and give rise to BASAL GANGLIA and cortical GABAergic and thalamic and olfactory INTERNEURONS.

name: Extravillous Trophoblasts
aka: Extravillous Trophoblast; Trophoblast, Extravillous
description: Differentiated trophoblast cells originally from trophoblastic cell columns of anchoring CHORIONIC VILLI of the DECIDUA basalis of the PLACENTA. Extravillous trophoblasts invade into the uterine structures, attaching the placenta to the UTERUS. They are also found in chorionic plate, MYOMETRIUM, and spiral arteries.

name: Erythroblasts
aka: Erythroblast
description: Immature, nucleated ERYTHROCYTES occupying the stage of ERYTHROPOIESIS that follows formation of ERYTHROID PRECURSOR CELLS and precedes formation of RETICULOCYTES. The normal series is called normoblasts. Cells called MEGALOBLASTS are a pathologic series of erythroblasts.

name: Erythrocyte Inclusions
aka: Erythrocyte Inclusion; Inclusion, Erythrocyte; Inclusions, Erythrocyte
description: Pathologic inclusions occurring in erythrocytes.

name: Erythrocyte Membrane
aka: Erythrocyte Membranes; Membrane, Erythrocyte
description: The semi-permeable outer structure of a red blood cell. It is known as a red cell 'ghost' after HEMOLYSIS.

name: Erythrocytes
aka: Erythrocyte
description: Red blood cells. Mature erythrocytes are non-nucleated, biconcave disks containing HEMOGLOBIN whose function is to transport OXYGEN.

name: Erythrocytes, Abnormal
description: Oxygen-carrying RED BLOOD CELLS in mammalian blood that are abnormal in structure or function.

name: Esophagogastric Junction
aka: Junction, Esophagogastric
description: The area covering the terminal portion of ESOPHAGUS and the beginning of STOMACH at the cardiac orifice.

name: Esophagus
description: The muscular membranous segment between the PHARYNX and the STOMACH in the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT.

name: Ethmoid Bone
aka: Bone, Ethmoid; Bones, Ethmoid; Ethmoid Bones
description: A light and spongy (pneumatized) bone that lies between the orbital part of FRONTAL BONE and the anterior of SPHENOID BONE. Ethmoid bone separates the ORBIT from the ETHMOID SINUS. It consists of a horizontal plate, a perpendicular plate, and two lateral labyrinths.

name: Ethmoid Sinus
aka: Sinus, Ethmoid
description: The numerous (6-12) small thin-walled spaces or air cells in the ETHMOID BONE located between the eyes. These air cells form an ethmoidal labyrinth.

name: Extrapyramidal Tracts
aka: Extrapyramidal Tract; Tract, Extrapyramidal
description: Uncrossed tracts of motor nerves from the brain to the anterior horns of the spinal cord, involved in reflexes, locomotion, complex movements, and postural control.

name: Eye
aka: Eyes
description: The organ of sight constituting a pair of globular organs made up of a three-layered roughly spherical structure specialized for receiving and responding to light.

name: Eyebrows
aka: Eyebrow
description: Curved rows of HAIR located on the upper edges of the eye sockets.

name: Eyelashes
description: The hairs which project from the edges of the EYELIDS.

name: Eyelids
aka: Eyelid
description: Each of the upper and lower folds of SKIN which cover the EYE when closed.

name: Facial Bones
aka: Bone, Facial; Bones, Facial; Facial Bone
description: The facial skeleton, consisting of bones situated between the cranial base and the mandibular region. While some consider the facial bones to comprise the hyoid (HYOID BONE), palatine (HARD PALATE), and zygomatic (ZYGOMA) bones, MANDIBLE, and MAXILLA, others include also the lacrimal and nasal bones, inferior nasal concha, and vomer but exclude the hyoid bone. (Jablonski, Dictionary of Dentistry, 1992, p113)

name: Facial Muscles
aka: Facial Muscle; Muscle, Facial; Muscles, Facial
description: Muscles of facial expression or mimetic muscles that include the numerous muscles supplied by the facial nerve that are attached to and move the skin of the face. (From Stedman, 25th ed)

name: Facial Nerve
aka: Facial Nerves; Nerve, Facial
description: The 7th cranial nerve. The facial nerve has two parts, the larger motor root which may be called the facial nerve proper, and the smaller intermediate or sensory root. Together they provide efferent innervation to the muscles of facial expression and to the lacrimal and SALIVARY GLANDS, and convey afferent information for TASTE from the anterior two-thirds of the TONGUE and for TOUCH from the EXTERNAL EAR.

name: Fallopian Tubes
aka: Tube, Fallopian; Tubes, Fallopian
description: A pair of highly specialized canals extending from the UTERUS to its corresponding OVARY. They provide the means for OVUM transport from the ovaries and they are the site of the ovum's final maturation and FERTILIZATION. The fallopian tube consists of an interstitium, an isthmus, an ampulla, an infundibulum, and fimbriae. Its wall consists of three layers: serous, muscular, and an internal mucosal layer lined with both ciliated and secretory cells.

name: Fascia
description: Layers of connective tissue of variable thickness. The superficial fascia is found immediately below the skin; the deep fascia invests MUSCLES, nerves, and other organs.

name: Fascia Lata
aka: Fascia Latas; Lata, Fascia; Latas, Fascia
description: CONNECTIVE TISSUE of the anterior compartment of the THIGH that has its origins on the anterior aspect of the iliac crest and anterior superior iliac spine, and its insertion point on the iliotibial tract. It plays a role in medial rotation of the THIGH, steadying the trunk, and in KNEE extension.

name: Femoral Artery
aka: Arteries, Femoral; Artery, Femoral; Femoral Arteries
description: The main artery of the thigh, a continuation of the external iliac artery.

name: Femoral Nerve
aka: Femoral Nerves; Nerve, Femoral; Nerves, Femoral
description: A nerve originating in the lumbar spinal cord (usually L2 to L4) and traveling through the lumbar plexus to provide motor innervation to extensors of the thigh and sensory innervation to parts of the thigh, lower leg, and foot, and to the hip and knee joints.

name: Femoral Vein
aka: Femoral Veins; Vein, Femoral; Veins, Femoral
description: The vein accompanying the femoral artery in the same sheath; it is a continuation of the popliteal vein and becomes the external iliac vein.

name: Femur
aka: Femurs
description: The longest and largest bone of the skeleton, it is situated between the hip and the knee.

name: Femur Head
aka: Femur Heads; Head, Femur
description: The hemispheric articular surface at the upper extremity of the thigh bone. (Stedman, 26th ed)

name: Femur Neck
aka: Neck, Femur
description: The constricted portion of the thigh bone between the femur head and the trochanters.

name: Fetal Blood
aka: Blood, Fetal; Bloods, Fetal; Fetal Bloods
description: Blood of the fetus. Exchange of nutrients and waste between the fetal and maternal blood occurs via the PLACENTA. The cord blood is blood contained in the umbilical vessels (UMBILICAL CORD) at the time of delivery.

name: Fetal Heart
aka: Fetal Hearts; Heart, Fetal; Hearts, Fetal
description: The heart of the fetus of any viviparous animal. It refers to the heart in the postembryonic period and is differentiated from the embryonic heart (HEART/embryology) only on the basis of time.

name: Fibula
aka: Fibulas
description: The bone of the lower leg lateral to and smaller than the tibia. In proportion to its length, it is the most slender of the long bones.

name: Finger Joint
aka: Finger Joints; Joint, Finger; Joints, Finger
description: The articulation between the head of one phalanx and the base of the one distal to it, in each finger.

name: Foam Cells
aka: Cell, Foam; Cells, Foam; Foam Cell
description: Lipid-laden macrophages originating from monocytes or from smooth muscle cells.

name: Foot Bones
aka: Bone, Foot; Bones, Foot
description: The TARSAL BONES; METATARSAL BONES; and PHALANGES OF TOES. The tarsal bones consists of seven bones: CALCANEUS; TALUS; cuboid; navicular; internal; middle; and external cuneiform bones. The five metatarsal bones are numbered one through five, running medial to lateral. There are 14 phalanges in each foot, the great toe has two while the other toes have three each.

name: Foramen Magnum
aka: Foramen Magnums; Magnum, Foramen; Magnums, Foramen
description: The large hole at the base of the skull through which the SPINAL CORD passes.

name: Fovea Centralis
description: An area approximately 1.5 millimeters in diameter within the macula lutea where the retina thins out greatly because of the oblique shifting of all layers except the pigment epithelium layer. It includes the sloping walls of the fovea (clivus) and contains a few rods in its periphery. In its center (foveola) are the cones most adapted to yield high visual acuity, each cone being connected to only one ganglion cell. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed)

name: Frontal Bone
aka: Bone, Frontal; Bones, Frontal; Frontal Bones
description: The bone that forms the frontal aspect of the skull. Its flat part forms the forehead, articulating inferiorly with the NASAL BONE and the CHEEK BONE on each side of the face.

name: Broca Area
aka: Area, Broca
description: Functional neuroanatomical region of the inferior frontal gyrus consisting of pars opercularis and pars triangularis. It is important in SPEECH and LANGUAGE production. Injuries to Broca area are associated with BROCA APHASIA and APRAXIA.

name: Frontal Lobe
aka: Frontal Lobes; Lobe, Frontal
description: The part of the cerebral hemisphere anterior to the central sulcus, and anterior and superior to the lateral sulcus.

name: Frontal Sinus
aka: Sinus, Frontal
description: One of the paired, but seldom symmetrical, air spaces located between the inner and outer compact layers of the FRONTAL BONE in the forehead.

name: Fundus Oculi
description: The concave interior of the eye, consisting of the retina, the choroid, the sclera, the optic disk, and blood vessels, seen by means of the ophthalmoscope. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed)

name: Gallbladder
aka: Gallbladders
description: A storage reservoir for BILE secretion. Gallbladder allows the delivery of bile acids at a high concentration and in a controlled manner, via the CYSTIC DUCT to the DUODENUM, for degradation of dietary lipid.

name: Ganglia
description: Clusters of multipolar neurons surrounded by a capsule of loosely organized CONNECTIVE TISSUE located outside the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM.

name: Ganglia, Autonomic
description: Clusters of neurons and their processes in the autonomic nervous system. In the autonomic ganglia, the preganglionic fibers from the central nervous system synapse onto the neurons whose axons are the postganglionic fibers innervating target organs. The ganglia also contain intrinsic neurons and supporting cells and preganglionic fibers passing through to other ganglia.

name: Ganglia, Parasympathetic
description: Ganglia of the parasympathetic nervous system, including the ciliary, pterygopalatine, submandibular, and otic ganglia in the cranial region and intrinsic (terminal) ganglia associated with target organs in the thorax and abdomen.

name: Ganglia, Spinal
description: Sensory ganglia located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column. The spinal ganglion cells are pseudounipolar. The single primary branch bifurcates sending a peripheral process to carry sensory information from the periphery and a central branch which relays that information to the spinal cord or brain.

name: Ganglia, Sympathetic
description: Ganglia of the sympathetic nervous system including the paravertebral and the prevertebral ganglia. Among these are the sympathetic chain ganglia, the superior, middle, and inferior cervical ganglia, and the aorticorenal, celiac, and stellate ganglia.

name: Gastric Fundus
aka: Fundus, Gastric
description: The superior portion of the body of the stomach above the level of the cardiac notch.

name: Gastric Mucosa
aka: Gastric Mucosas; Mucosa, Gastric; Mucosas, Gastric
description: Lining of the STOMACH, consisting of an inner EPITHELIUM, a middle LAMINA PROPRIA, and an outer MUSCULARIS MUCOSAE. The surface cells produce MUCUS that protects the stomach from attack by digestive acid and enzymes. When the epithelium invaginates into the LAMINA PROPRIA at various region of the stomach (CARDIA; GASTRIC FUNDUS; and PYLORUS), different tubular gastric glands are formed. These glands consist of cells that secrete mucus, enzymes, HYDROCHLORIC ACID, or hormones.

name: Geniculate Bodies
aka: Bodies, Geniculate; Geniculate Body
description: Part of the DIENCEPHALON inferior to the caudal end of the dorsal THALAMUS. Includes the lateral geniculate body which relays visual impulses from the OPTIC TRACT to the calcarine cortex, and the medial geniculate body which relays auditory impulses from the lateral lemniscus to the AUDITORY CORTEX.

name: Geniculate Ganglion
aka: Ganglion, Geniculate
